block.p: Ethiopian Rebels Hit Oil Site Separatist rebels stormed a Chinese-run oil field in eastern Ethiopia, killing more than 70 people, including nine Chinese workers, in one of Ethiopia's worst rebel attacks in years. After a fierce hourlong battle, the attackers rushed away, taking at least six Chinese hostages with them.
PAGE A6

A Push for Education The billionaires Bill Gates and Eli Broad will spend $60 million to try to vault education high on the agenda of the 2008 presidential race. They plan to run advertisements calling for more consistent curriculum standards, a longer school day and merit pay for teachers.
PAGE A21

Acquittal in Indonesia An Indonesian court acquitted Newmont Mining, an American company, and one of its senior executives of charges of polluting a bay with toxic waste, in a case that became a litmus test of foreign investor confidence in Indonesia.
PAGE A8
About New York In his first About New York column, Jim Dwyer details the plight of a father and son who were detained as protesters during the Republican National Convention.
PAGE B1
New Planet May Be Earthlike Astronomers have discovered a planet 20 light-years from Earth and within the so-called habitable zone from its star.
PAGE A16

A New Leader in Auto Sales In Detroit, the news that Toyota had, at least for the most recent quarter, unseated General Motors as the world's top-selling automobile company was greeted with some anguish, some anger and a sense of resignation.
BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1
Mexico City Allows Abortion Mexico City approved a bill to permit abortion in the first three months of pregnancy, setting the stage for battles in court and between conservatives and liberals.
